response.answer_text: How do you become famous? - [Overnight Fame] I have seen many people ask on the internet how anyone can become famous overnight? OR how to become famous? OR how do I become famous?  But why do you want to become famous, there are many people including me, who don’t want to become famous. We are good and famous in the eyes of our parents, siblings and friends. But, if you still want to become famous, then I will give you the most recent example of the young Egyptian girl named “Sarah Abouelkhair” who became famous just by making an Instagram story. Is it really possible in today's world? what will you say? If I say “YES”. On Oct 22, 2018, the girl named “Sarah Abouelkhair” did something, which shocked the whole social media - particularly Instagram & Facebook. Sarah (who has 35.1k Insta Followers) made an Instagram story named “BBQ” with a picture of official NASA logo and tagged NASA organization in her story, as you can check in the attached picture.  The whole Instagram story has 32 images. I will try my best to cut off the unnecessary images to reduce the post length. I think I don’t need to explain everything mentioned in the images, you can better judge it by yourself and easily depict the whole idea, what she is trying to explain in those images. So the first picture starts with the most brilliant and Awesome idea, which she just got from nowhere but from her own mind (Her Instincts). She really wanted to give her brilliant idea to NASA (The National Aeronautics and Space Administration). Sarah’s original Quote: Hi, NASA. I have an Amazing idea for you. I won’t change for it, although it’s genius and I probably should.”  LOL [Amazing Idea] for NASA…. :) Check the 2nd image, in which she explained her idea a little bit more with proper image and text. What if before rocket launches - Hear me out? we put a giant Grill with tons of Chicken, Cow, and other Halal animals meat…. :P  Like this, as shown in the attached image - Giant Grill - My personal question to Sarah is that how are we supposed to get the big giant grill?  Hahaha! When the engine of a space rocket starts, then Rocket engine produces thrust by the expulsion of an exhaust Fluid (Hydrogen Gas with a mixture of other lighter gases).  After that, the whole meat party will begin. “Less Labor - More Flavour” Cheesy Fiesta! She explained her logic in the given way; BBQ for Everyone in NASA! in less than a minute (60 seconds)  She didn’t end up here. She explained the whole science with the idea. She said, that this idea will not stop here, this idea can also do the following: 5 Misconceptions or Myths of Sarah’s Idea! Save Energy - More rockets, more baked chicken.It will end the World HungerIt will probably get her a decent job at NASA.It will increase the NASA productivity (better than SpaceX)It will reduce the overall cost of food on the day of the robot launching. In her Instagram story, she also asked the question to all of her followers in a more decent and stylish way. She asked - Should NASA Universe Education just hire me for my creative ideas on saving the World 1 BBQ at a time? NASA PLSHELL NO After that, she shared a screenshot of the private message, which she received from NASA after her story becomes viral on Instagram and Social media websites.  She also shared another message which she got from SpaceX (company) company.  She also shared another message which she got from it from BuzzFeed - BuzzFeed, Inc. is an American Internet media and news company based in New York City. They wanted to conduct an interview with her in order to cover the whole story. They also asked for her permission though. [Over night Success and Fame] - Right na?  Another message from Netflix (product) - they wanted to document the whole journey in an exclusive short when she will spend her day with SpaceX.  She even shared & attached the picture with her family including her parents which she took outside the Kennedy Space Center, Orlando.  Everyone was so confused at that point. How did the 2 most famous and biggest companies respond to her in just 1 or 3 days? OR how her story gets noticed by SpaceX and NASA, because every day, they received notifications of the tags that people used in which their names are present. But what was the actual story behind this amazing and creative idea?? no one knows exactly - Everyone just amazed, shocked and confused, just like me when I first saw her Insta story via my Friend’s profile. Sarah’s Instagram story also contained the message of “Ellen” - TheEllenShow Host (The EllenShow features comic Ellen DeGeneres in the studio performing an opening monologue and interviewing guests who include celebrities, newsmakers and ordinary people with extraordinary talents. )  Just check her overall excitement, when she got famous in just 10 minutes after getting an overwhelming response from SpaceX, NASA, Netflix, Outback, Buzzfeed and TheEllenShow.  Let me tell you something (To all of my viewers) Actually, all the screenshots were real. She got those Instagram messages in a real-time. She has over 35.1K Instagram followers and with her story of All tags related to NASA, SpaceX, BBQ, and the amazing Idea got her a massive influence of people out there. This is the power of Social media, which we cannot neglect in today’s world. There are many examples of these types of fame, success, and stardom. Many people become Millionaire, celebrities, models, etc. by using Social Media influence and power. The given attached picture will clear all your confusions and misconceptions about her.  So actually, she was performing a social experiment to let the world know about the futility and influence of social media, and how social media can be used to promote fake or hyped news.  After the whole social experiment, she also sent a message to NASA official account and explained the whole experiment which was conducted at that time. After 4 to 5 days of the experiment, she also got offered amazing gifts from major companies……[ANY IDEA CAN BE BIG & AMAZING]  Check the attached screenshot containing the message of “Salma El Bouyahyaoui (@namelessamlas) • Instagram photos and videos”  In this way, she got new Instagram followers and her followers keep increasing now. I’ll answer this for school, roughly 11–18 and female. Generally popular girls are pretty and blonde. The ‘queen bee’ specially is the prettiest and is blonde. At my school, you had to care about your grades, so you work hard and try to make the teachers like you. This doesn’t mean that you have to get straight As, but you need to be within the top 25%. You have a large group of friends and you’re all in the sports teams together, ideally as many as possible. The most popular girl at my school was in every team by the time she left. I think this was specific to my school, but there was a metal badge system, one per sport or club. To get these, you needed to represent the school at an event and attend the meetings regularly. Aim to get as many as possible, ideally the sports ones and a few others. If you can’t get one, pick up any you find around school, or ask teachers that like you if they have any in their desk drawers. If there’s a uniform, shorten your skirt, tuck your blouse in enough, but not too much. Wear short socks and lace up shoes. As you’re sporty, you have lots of pairs of bright, Nike trainers, and you get new pairs regularly. Unlike currently, the trainers are all thin and not clumpy. Have the coolest backpack - lots of bright colours, but either remove the brand name or ensure it isn’t traceable - you don’t want anyone else to find/have the same one as you. During non school uniform days, wear clothes that are on trend, and well kept. Ideally, you would have clothes that no one else has. If it is a themed day, go all out. take pictures of these, with you in the middle and put them on your social media. As you’re the head of your friendship group, you need to be loud and sociable all the time. You need to ensure that you have a few interesting stories to tell about you at any time, for all conversations. If you have lots of siblings, this’ll help. People at my school were always more popular if they had lots of siblings - 2 or 3 being ideal. Say hi to your siblings and their friends in the corridors. Most important: identify anyone who might threaten your existence and welcome them into your group. for example, there was a girl I knew who was insanely jealous of the most popular girl, was on the fringes of the group & would’ve spread rumours about her etc. This girl had no siblings and was a spoilt and lonely girl. everything the most popular girl had, she wanted. So, what you do is make her your best friend. become inseparable: do all your lessons together, invite her to your house, call her your sister, share your snacks, let her choose the classroom music, ask her to help you with your homework, let her play with your hair etc. If there are some people on the edge of your group, who you don’t think like you as much as you’d like them to, treat them in a similar way for a week or so, to strengthen their friendship with you. at the same time, try to make the rest of the class like you. do silly things in lessons that make them laugh. volunteer for science experiments in class, chat to them about whether or not you’re getting an exercise correct, show off how neat your work/ planner (diary) is, show off your tan, chat about the funny thing one of your siblings did at the weekend etc. A good trick is to annoy the teacher until they’re exasperated and then behave beautifully for the next 15 minutes and repeat. Other things to note: always be on time for lessons - a few minutes early is idealhaving straight hair is helpful, as it’ll always look neatwear several bracelets at all times, so you can fiddle with them in lessonsget people to play with your hair if you’re not being noticeddo daring things - sit on top of the lockers, walk across the desks, leave campus at lunch (forbidden) etc.have lots of delicious snackshave a link to a far away (ideally hot) country, go there often, in your winteras above, get tanned easilybe tall and thincomplete all homework on time - bonus if it’s in the lesson or day it was set in, and store it neatly - no crumpled edgeshave neat handwriting, pretend you don’t like itmove seats in lessons where the teacher won’t mind/noticewrite in the wrong coloured pen and then tell the teacher it was an accidenthave new, cool stationery - rearrange it in lessons that bore you, ideally no one else would have stationery like yours, so lots of people ask to use/fiddle with it and want to know where it’s from. better still if you let a pen roll across the desk, so more people noticehave a rich family (like the sibling thing, I don’t know why this is important but it is)go on holiday often - ski in winter, beach in summer, other holidays in betweeninvite lots of friends for sleepovers, ideally 4 + at onceAll in all, you need to make sure you have lots of friends that like you, both in your year and other years. You need to set the trends and be slightly ahead of the curve in everything. Be slightly disruptive, but not too much. Make sure the teachers all like you. Ensure you lead what looks like a charmed life, and most importantly - appear to do all of the above with ease.

I’m assuming you’re thinking of showbusiness so here goes: Make an honest list of your talents and shortcomings and work on perfecting yourself. Take music lessons and train your voice. Learn to read sheet music. Lots of pop musicians can’t read music, but you’ll have more independence if you can and it’ll help with songwriting. Take acting classes. See as much live theatre and live concert performance as you can. I used to live in a house-share with 2 fledgling actors and a young lady who really wanted to be a singer. She could sing quite well but never got anywhere because she wasn’t playing the game right. Showbusiness is really hard to break into. You have to keep on and on pushing and be persistent: play the long game. Elvis Presley, the Beatles and Madonna were all turned down and faced rejections at the beginning of their careers. Don’t rely on any one person. Judge people on results, not empty promises. Stay away from drugs, they’ve never helped anyone’s career. Know the business (find out as much as you can). The world is changing. Think about learning a foreign language. It could open up all kinds of doors. E.g. suppose you have blond hair and blue eyes and yet speak fluent Chinese — as an actor you’d be filling a niche in a potentially lucrative overseas marketplace). If you have any talent for writing you can use this — not just for songwriting, but you could write your own movies. Professional-grade equipment is easy to come by and you can now edit a film digitally on a computer. It’s possible to make a pretty good movie for a few thousand dollars, so this is something you could think about. And you need to be businesslike. If you do make that movie, you don’t sell it outright. You cut deals where people buy distribution rights in certain territories for a certain number of years. Social media of course is the way to get noticed nowadays. If you can get yourself a whole crowd of followers you’ve got your foot half in the door already. If you’re interested in working in TV as a presenter or host, most of these people are professional journalists. Usually you would start off as a researcher and work your way up. Even entry-level jobs are hard to get in TV so the way in is via voluntary work where you can help out and you get to see how a TV production is actually made. As a presenter you’re not just working in front of the camera but behind it as well. You’d quite possibly be required to write your own scripts and you need to know how to edit your own work on a computer. Re television I’m speaking from experience by the way. Years ago I worked at a TV station in a voluntary capacity. I wrote factsheets (this was before everyone had the internet) and answered the phone. We got to watch the local news as it was going out. TV studios are much smaller in reality than they look on screen. There are some good courses out there that will teach you the technical aspects of TV and internet journalism. In closing I would say remember fame is fickle, showbusiness and the media are intensely competitive fields. Even if you reach the top, nobody stays there for ever. Being famous must be pretty tiring. (No wonder so many of the top stars want to go into early retirement!)

This can be a long one but useful: Learn the exact characteristics and behaviors that will let people like you: Most people want to be socially desirable and do everything they can to make that happen. Yet, despite their sincere efforts, they often are not effective in increasing their popularity. Even when their friends sincerely try to shore them up, encouraging them to look at their positive attributes, they know that something is just not right. Some know that they choke in social situations whenever the topic becomes too uncomfortable to talk about. Others tell me that they just can’t think of what to say in the moment to keep the conversation going and begin to feel awkward in trying to continue. But many are just confused, not understanding why others see them as they do. Frustrated and discouraged, they desperately want to know what they can do to solve their socially painful dilemma. Sometimes, of course, it is just a matter of being born with a socially desirable personality, but many of the behaviors that make people popular can actually be learned. I firmly believe that people who have not been able to hold their audiences can learn how to both bring people closer and keep from pushing them away. The first step in learning any new way of being is to courageously look at what has not worked in the past. Exploring past social faux pas is hard for anyone and will only help if any negative self-judgments are put aside in the process. Prior social mistakes leave painful scars for everyone, but, if they are seen as learning experiences, they can be the foundation of what to leave behind and to activate the motivation to learn what does work. There are basic personality characteristics and specific behaviors that can either turn people away or make them want to come closer. The first category is actually easier. Most people can readily learn what they might be doing that either bores or alienates others. The second, acquiring the personality characteristics and behaviors that attract, takes more practice, but once achieved, is extraordinarily rewarding. Common Personality Characteristics That Turn People Off: 1) Insecurity Insecurity usually manifests as a strong need for approval. Insecure people try too hard and often respond too quickly to an interaction. They rapidly agree, sometimes when they inwardly disagree, and put others on a pedestal. 2) Low Energy Passive, non-reactive people tend to come across as uninterested and bored. Though they may feel quite differently inside, their demeanor signals a desire for minimal engagement and puts the pressure on the other person to carry the energy of the interaction. 3) Self-Centered People who take center stage in conversations do not usually hold their audiences for long unless they happen to be charismatic, notable, entertaining, or famous. Most self-centered people push their audiences away. Though they may just be nervous underneath, the people on the other end of them don’t recognize or think about those inner feelings. 4) Seemingly Uninterested If a person looks or feels bored, the person talking isn’t likely to continue for very long. Even if people feel uninterested, they can help the conversation get livelier. You generally can’t be bored without being boring. 5) Inflammatory Biases When people use social interactions to express rigid or fixed ideas, they will most likely engender defensiveness or exclusion in those who feel differently. An opinionated orientation without openness to other views tells others that they have no other choice but to agree, defend, or bolt. 6) Sarcasm Sarcasm is the most misunderstood of all humor. Sarcastic people take a big chance of coming across as insulting if others don’t see the humor or are offended by it. What may be funny or welcome challenge to one person can easily be a turn-off to another. Common Personality Characteristics That Attract Others: 1) Openness to new Ideas Everyone sees the world differently and usually enjoys sharing his or her views with an interested listener. Even if people disagree with the other’s reality, they can try to better understand each other if there is no judgment or counter-argument. In a good, well-timed conversation, there is always enough time and interest for both people to share their own views and experiences, even when they might see things differently. 2) Being genuinely interested A good way to define curiosity is genuine interest in what is yet to be known. People who are in demand approach others with a genuine desire to know them. That behavior is reflected in their sincere questions, their active responses, their obvious interest in what is being shared, and the pleasure they show. 3) Energy Passion for life can be expressed in many ways, but energy tells the tale. It is the opposite of a lackluster, dull response. Most everyone enjoys listening to someone who is excited to be in the conversation, active in their responses, and enthusiastic about what is going on. 4) Sense of Humor It is always important that people in personal conversations know when it’s appropriate to laugh and when to take things seriously. Conversations work best when both people have the capacity to participate, to lighten a situation up, and to play when it is appropriate. Those characteristics put people at ease and keep a conversation meaningful at the same time. 5) Being Present to Cues Many people are so focused on what they are thinking that they fail to pick up cues from the other that keep conversations mutually satisfying. People who pay attention to the way someone sounds, looks, feels, and acts, are more likely to notice a shift in the interaction and act accordingly. 6) Empathic People who attract others have a natural tendency to be compassionate and supportive. They feel when another is uneasy or nervous, and compensate by adjusting their tone and response style. They notice when the person talking to them rapidly changes the subject or looks uncomfortable. There is nothing to say more than what i’m going to say now, the most important thing of all is, what you think of youself in your mind. If you want to achieve anything, start with achieving your own mind and make it under your own control. Be the one to express your inner mind.

The basic formula which I believe to become “Famous” are as follows - Master the ability to sell.Fix your target audience. This will go a huge way in choosing your product (literally anything -products, services, talents, emotions etc.) and platform (literally anything too, Academics, Arts, Sports etc in real life, Academics, Arts, Sports etc on social sites etc.)Based on the above two, sell your product effectively to the target audience on your preferred platform. If they like it, they would come back,then even more would get to know and like it, and sooner than later, you will be famous.Selling is everything. Every famous person has something to sell. Artists sell their Art (Actors/Singers/Dancers/Painters etc.(the order is in descending fame)) Sports Stars sell (perform) their skills. Geniuses sell their skills. (Inventing, researching etc.) Rich people sell their monetary collection and so on and so forth. Generic advice on becoming famous in the years to come - Choose you target audience properly. They are the ones who are going to make you famous. Audiences can make or break you.Ensure the strength of your audience is to your satisfaction i.e ensuring the platform is worth it and to your content. Eg:-Being the most famous player in, say Squash/Chess, does not even come close to the popularity an above average player gets in Soccer/Cricket or NFL/NBA/MLBA person having 15k followers on a platform of 100k may be relatively more famous to a person having 200k followers on a platform of a billion, but doesn’t enjoy the same status the 200k person enjoys.Pewdiepie is more famous than Balaji Vishwanathan, even though BV is more talented than Pew. (no offense to BV)In short, the more their strength, the better.Behave as your audience wants you to. You won’t sell effectively if the audience are Teens and your actions are presumed preachy/wise. Similarly, you won’t go anywhere if you write Academic Research reports like you write a Tweet.You could piggyback the ride to your fame by several underhanded means -Challenge existing famous persons, publicly - If the person ignores you, you can continue to challenge them and insult them, creating the view that they are afraid of you, thus boosting your fame. If they accept and lose, you could sound the bugle forever staking that you are better than them and thereby, becoming famous. If they win, you can still claim you were nearly as good as them and capture the sympathies of their audience. So its Win-Win-Win situation and an easy ticket to fame.Create controversies - People love to watch controversies, even if they claim they don’t. Accuse a popular person of something, lie through your teeth. If they don’t respond, they are seen as defensive and hence some sympathy is created for you and your lies are believed to be true. If they do respond, well hey, their entire audience now knows you and therefore, you are famous too. No publicity is bad publicity.Fake it till you make it - You can always pretend that you know what you are doing and are good at it. Repeatedly stating that you are good will actually create an illusion among your audience that, “Hey, he might be right” and that is another ticket to your fame.Outright steal someone else’s work - Once you start climbing the ladder and are out of quality content, you can always steal a relatively unknown’s work and pass it as your own. If he fights back, you could pay him some hush money from the wealth you generate or convince your audience that you were the Original and not him.You cannot NOT account for opportunity. No matter how skilled or talented, how hard you have practiced, unless you are presented with the opportunity, you won’t be successful, and therefore famous. Some are showered with opportunity around every corner, mostly due to the fact that they are related to existing famous personalities or they are associated with the people who are in power of the platform. This is demonstrated by Nepotism, Unfair selection means etc. But hey again, once you are famous, who cares about how you started. Even if they do, who will fight against it. Pfft, you are set for life.Or you could rise to fame the usual way, with Talent, Practice and a little bit of luck.Thank me when you are famous :D ╱╱┏╮╱╱┃┃▉━╯┗━╮▉┈┈┈┈┃▉╮┈┈┈┃╱╰━━━╯

You don't become popular. Popularity is a complex matter. Being popular means being admired by many people. In order to be admired by many people you need to be similar to them yet stand out as above average in many areas the others perceive as important. So being popular is about matching perfectly with a certain environment. If you take out an extremely popular person from their natural environment to one where they are the typical fish out of the water, their status changes instantly. Let's take as example four fictional characters. (they are extremely stereotypical representations to help me pass the message) Abigail is the typical teenage movies popular girl with more beauty than brain. She attends a local high school where sports are more important than the actual studies. She is captain of the cheerleading team and she decides who is cool and who is not (she has that power). She thinks she is God and she bullies poor girls because they are fat and/or ugly. She is a drama queen and a real bitch but somehow she is the real deal. Fernando is a Mexican student, small, horrible haircut, fat, and with extra large clothes that make him look even more fat. He's shy and not at all assertive. A real loser. But he is extremely intelligent. Maybe too much: he studied 30 languages among which Middle Dutch, Old Tamil and High Valyrian, plus he created a language himself. What a weird guy, maybe he has Asperger. Who is ever going to like him? Mike is a man on his 40s, he is a carpenter, works in a very small company of 15 people. He is extremely arrogant and racist. He shares the most disturbing porn movies with his colleague and he is an incredible binge drinker. His colleagues think he is very cool and are very loyal to him. Nobody cares about him being fat and having an enormous beer belly because his very unhealthy lifestyle. In fact on his work he is very reliable and competent. Kevin is a college student. He is the prototype of the guy everyone loves. He speaks perfect Spanish, being in love with the South American cultures, he is a great soccer player, he has multiple creative talents like singing and drawing, he is incredible handsome and gains money with modelling, he has incredibly high scores and of course a lot of friends. He is always extremely kind with everyone and does even volunteering. Who is ever going to dislike him? The point is: Abigail, Mike and Kevin are at the top of their environments, and they are judged for completely different characteristics. Fernando is an outcast and he looks like a lost case, but is it over for him? What happens when these guys are moved to different environments? Abigail ends the high school and goes to the same college where Kevin is studying. Nobody is impressed by her poor attitude and slutty and bitchy behaviour. Everybody dislikes her and finds her arrogant. Abigail is now an outcast. Fernando completes his studies with the highest grades and takes a PHD in linguistics. He quickly becomes the big deal in his field due to his extreme competence and intelligence. He is now popular and enjoy having very nice conversations about his studies and his other nerd hobbies. Mike wins a holiday in a very luxury resort where he goes with his wife. The rich attendants of the resort stare at him with a puzzling look that seems to say: "what is this uneducated rude man doing here?". He casually starts a conversation at the café with a distinct man and tells him that “the police should shoot those Mexican monkeys that enter in the USA without permission". The man does what every educated man would do, answering nothing and leaving disgusted. Whenever Mike states similar sentences among his peers, they always laugh and agree with him. Here, it wasn't exactly the same. Kevin decides to try out powerlifting, and joins a local gym where also a colleague of Mike and some of his friends train. It turns out that the environment in that particular gym is an extremely macho one. Kevin is ridiculed to be ‘the skinny guy that doesn't even deadlift 220 lbs', a ‘pretty face with a vagina’ and ‘friend of the Mexican monkeys’ - yes, Kevin makes the mistake to mention that he went on holidays in Spain. Kevin leaves the gym after 4 training sessions. He's not home there. — Have you ever had a ‘popular for one day’ experience? Do something so good people have to talk about it. Save someone’s life in an amazing way. Survive a disaster in the most amazing way. Do something clever to make someone’s life better. Do something so bad people have to talk about it. …I’m not listing ideas, but, be Hitler, King Herod, or a terrorist. I don’t recommend this as a goal… Do anything extreme/strange/weird/unique that will catch attention. Make a giant steel sculpture version of an everyday object for a park. Become a one-hit-wonder with a cheesy song with sexual innuendos and unintelligible vocalization parts that gets played on various radio stations. Bike across the world through wind, rain, and snow, with a three-legged cat in your backpack. Never shave your face for the rest of your life and end up with a 6 foot. dreaded beard. Jokes aside, gaining fame is one of those things that (most) everyone wants to have but no one can ever control. It’s always hit or miss. No matter what you’re making, producing, becoming, what you are, what you want to do, what you’ve done, what level it’s done at, no matter how crazy, subtle, extreme, lightly, or any other adjective you can think of, you cannot gain and receive fame on your control. You can try to gain fame and it could work immediately, you could try to work for fame and it not happen until 6 years of steady trying, or you could try to work for fame and never get it. It’s completely unpredictable. You shouldn’t do something just so you’ll be famous. There’s no joy or really no point in it and you’ll almost always lose yourself in the process. The best way to possibly gain any sort of fame is when you are doing/making/creative/being something because you love it and are passionate about it. The more passionate you are, the more heart and soul you’ll put into it and the more people will notice. People love to see other people excited by their passions and this can elicit fame for some. Just like Pete Nelson, the “Treehouse Man” of the show Treehouse Masters:  Kim Kimble, hairstylist of top, A-list celebrities:  Or the late, great painter Bob Ross:  People don’t love them because they desired to be famous. People love them because they just did what made them happy and wanted to share it with the world. People also love them because they are (or were, for the latter) genuine people and they became EXPERTS at what they do (did) not because they wanted to be recognized and famous for being an expert, but because their passion drives (drove) them to practice over and over and learn all there is to learn about their trades, and they want(ed) to share the products of their passions with others. It’s ironic in nature that it seems the less one is worried about fame, the more likely one will gain it, but that is often just the way it is (and much better for your mental/emotional health in the long run!). Plus, the more you focus on your passion and what makes you happy, the less you’ll probably find the idea of fame and gaining it to be so important.

So if you want to get famous, be sure you research what is out there first.

Are you here to learn to be famous? Cause famous is cool. Famous is fun. Famous is attractive.  but WAIT! Think for a second though. maybe we’re aiming for the wrong thing? Instead of famous. Why not RICH? Why RICH is better: 1) You focus on what truly matters. Whenever you create something you’re proud of, there’s a natural tendency to want to tell everybody about your success. Look at me. I am so great! The more you share, the more addicted you become to the attention and the less you focus on the work that made you proud in the first place. There are people who are trapped in a cyclone of self-validation, e.g., constantly posting selfies of a new look on Twitter, showing off a new car on Facebook, or writing about yet another fabulous vacation on Instagram. Think about it. If your self-esteem is strong, why do you need to tell anybody about anything you do? 2) You become impervious to insults. After you’ve been called a loser, an idiot, arrogant, out of touch, shameful, a dickhead, a chink, and many other epithets, your mind turns bulletproof. After all, when you’re already a nobody, nothing can be any lower. 3) You can live your life in peace. Being famous is a curse. Yet, for some reason, kids seem to have an insatiable desire for worldwide attention. What the hell happened? Is it due to social media or bad parenting or both? When you’re famous, many people want something from you, mostly your time. And given time is more valuable than money, being known robs you of your most precious asset. 4) There are no expectations of you. When you’re a nobody, nobody expects you to do anything or do anything special. Therefore, you can regularly surpass expectations.  An advice I find powerful and freeing: “All this desire for fame and prestige is truly a waste of time. Get your 15 minutes of fame to satisfy your curiosity. Maybe get 30 minutes just to be sure. Soak up the thrill. Then let it go.” Source

How to Become Famous So you've decided - you want to become famous! Fame certainly has its perks, and you'll find there are many paths to get to fame. One of the best ones is to develop a talent. Then, you can market yourself and that talent to the world, building your base and making you famous. Keep in mind that it often takes a lot of work to become and stay famous, so if you're not willing to work hard, this path may not be the one for you. Plus, even if you work your hardest, you may still not become famous, as it takes an element of luck, as well. Method One of Three:Finding a Path to Fame 1Decide how famous you want to be. Fame comes at many different levels. For instance, you could be famous in your school or workplace. You could be famous in your hometown or your state. Alternatively, you could go for ultimate fame and attempt to be famous around the world. Each of these has its own unique pros and cons, so it's up to you to decide how much fame you want.2Create a unique solution to a problem. Think about the problems in your life and in the world around you. If you can come up with a unique solution or a unique invention, you may become famous for it.[1]For example, Marie Curie became famous as a scientist and inventor of the X-ray.Think about problems in your life. Maybe you're always late, or you hate having to hunt around for your shoes everyday. What solutions could you come up with to help yourself and others with these problems?Advertisement3Stand out from other people. Sometimes, you'll get noticed for just being yourself, if you have a unique way of doing things or a unique way of looking at the world. The key is to go your own way and be just who you are. You shouldn't change how you do things just because you do them in a unique or odd way.Break away from stereotypes. If you love to skateboard, find your own unique tricks. Instead of going for a typical "skater" look, find your own flair.4Audition for a reality show. Another way people become famous is by going on reality shows. You don't necessarily need a talent to get on a reality show, though in some cases, you'll need one, such as with singing shows. Look on the shows' websites to find out where and when you can audition.Generally, it helps to be enthusiastic when you audition, particularly about the show.Keep in mind, on reality competition shows, the judges may be tough or mean. Don't take it too personally, though. It's a part of the show5Be generous in a unique way. While this may seem counter-intuitive, some people become famous by doing something for other people in a really unusual way. It could be making a large donation, but you could also just raise money in some way that's out of the ordinary.For instance, one man, Si Burgher had famously long eyebrows, nearly 3 inches (7.6 cm)! When friends suggested he let people shave them off to raise money for charity, he agreed and became famous in his hometown of Bloomfield, Indiana.[2]For example, you could make it your goal to bake and sell a million brownies to raise money for a cause.Advertisement6Work on a world record. Another way you might become famous is by breaking a world record. Read through the world records, and figure out if you could work on one to break.[3]Keep in mind, your world record will likely need to be verified by a Guinness Book of World Record's official. Plus, to truly get famous this way, you need to pick a record that people care about, rather than just any record.7Post a silly video. In a social media-driven world, you can win 5 minutes of fame by posting a goofy video that takes the internet by storm. It doesn't have to be anything terribly difficult. It just has to be engaging and entertaining. It can involve something as simple as your cat doing something funny.[4]You might post a video of you playing a funny song on your instrument, or doing something funny in a public place. Get creative, and make sure you're having fun! If you're enjoying yourself, your audience is more likely to like the video!

7 Simple Ways To Be Famous In One Year 1. Begin By Making It All About Others, Not Yourself If you are going to reach niche celebrity status, your first step is to become a truly trusted resource for others. This means that you do the following: Inspire, entertain and educate others without thought to making sales or promoting yourself or your business Be a real person behind that company, not a faceless entity Be accessible and transparent; have a social media presence that involves conversations; answer emails; be present wherever there are important conversations occurring, especially in groups related to your niche Do not be “better” than others; rather be helpful and friendly and humble Engage others daily, especially influencers. Hanging out with influencers makes you one too. If you succeed, don’t be the first one to boast, but try to share the lessons you’ve learn and inspire other people to follow your path. And if you don’t succeed from the first attempt, don’t be discreet about your failure either. There’s nothing wrong with making mistakes and talking about that, rather than trying to appear as a super human. Compare this to the traditional concept of a supposed industry leader – one who gave an occasional interview; one who had “gatekeepers;” one who knew s/he was “better” than the others; one who was inaccessible. This won’t work for you, because you don’t have any fame yet. 2. Get Your Face and Your Personality “Out There” Brands are not really spread by products and services anymore. They are spread by personalities on social websites and news media. It’s almost as if we have returned to days of old when storekeepers had personal relationships with all of their customers. Of course, these can no longer be face-to-face, but they can be strong relationships nevertheless. Today’s digital consumers of anything demand relationships. If you have written a book, for example, you need to show online communities who you are, your sense of humor, your sense of compassion, your incredible expertise, whatever it is that makes you a bit of a “giant” in your niche. Provide excerpts from that book for free to every digital community possible. Set up book signings everywhere possible and call the local news media to cover them. Offer an additional benefit with a book purchase. Get buzz going by pushing your face and your personality, not just your book. ⌄ Scroll down to continue reading article ⌄ Always Putting Things off Until Tomorrow? Grab your FREE Lifehack guide to learn how to take action now and make your goal happen! Your Best Email Address Download Now Free ⌄ Scroll down to continue reading article ⌄ Inject your personality into everything you do online and on the ground. If you are in a business niche, hold events, make videos, and plaster them all over the place. Feature your customers in your blog posts, on your social media platforms. Do anything that you can to spread your brand by spreading the people factor, not by pushing the product or service. Come up with something that people will look forward to every week – things that will draw them to you and make them draw their communities to you too. 3. Provide Consistent, Public, Interesting, and Free Content Jack Daniels is a well-known brand. It has been a well-known brand for years. And it has done this by consistently keeping itself in front of the public. Now, in years past it relied on TV advertising – expensive advertising. Advertising that those of us who would just like to become famous in our niche cannot afford. We have to find cheap ways to become famous, and even Jack Daniels is going the cheap route now. It’s not all over TV – that’s a thing of the past. What does Jack Daniels do now? It has an amazing website and an amazing social media presence. It sponsors contests for people to submit new drink recipes. It asks customers to submit weird bar stories, which it publishes – consumers love it and they continue to love Jack Daniels. Jack Daniels will be famous for years to come because it understand how fame is now built. When you use the same strategies that Jack Daniels uses, you can build your fame too. Get your “public” involved in everything you do. Other than the cost of maintaining your websites and social media platforms through employees or contractors, your cost of providing amazing and interest and entertaining and inspirational content is cheap. No one wants to read what looks like a textbook; and no one want to just hear about products. They want some fun and some education and they want it in engaging ways. Even if your niche seems “boring”, there’s still a way to interact with your audience successfully and leveraging your authority status. Simply, by offering free detailed information of every aspect related to your business. For instance, Moverscorp publishes loads of amazing guides, covering pretty much any aspect of moving – from choosing the company to packing to tipping movers and things to do after the move. You can build your fame if you are committed to giving your public the best content ever. On the Internet there are no walls and there are few rules. You build a fan base and that fan base reaches out to its communities, as long as your content is great. People share what is free and what is publicly provided. So give free and public! 4. Sponsor an Important Charity One of the best ways to enhance your fame is to sponsor a well-known and compassionate charitable cause. You can do wonderful good while you increase your fame as well. Why do people love Toms Shoes, and why has Toms Shoes become so famous? Because owner Blake Mycoskie, “chief shoe giver,” donates a pair of shoes to a needy child for every pair of shoes he sells. And he has branched out now into efforts for restoring eyesight and drilling water in 3rd world countries. He is a hero, especially among millennials, the biggest buying demographic, for all that he does. And he has great fame within his niche. ⌄ Scroll down to continue reading article ⌄ Get That Goal You've Always Wanted Grab a FREE Lifehack Guide to start getting what you want! Reach My Goal! ⌄ Scroll down to continue reading article ⌄ Jessica Erickson, owner of Headbands for Hope has gained national fame for her charitable work with children’s cancer research and her donations of headbands to young girls with cancer. If you want to make a difference in the lives of people and gain fame as well, this is a great path. Local, regional and state media love these kinds of stories, and the reach spreads. Both Mycoskie and Erickson have been featured on national television shows several times. 5. Develop Relationships with Influencers There are famous people in related niches. Influencers are already famous within their niches. One of the “rules” for success is to hang out with successful people. The same goes in the digital world. You can “follow” influencers, participate in their discussions, and make yourself known as an expert in your niche. Cultivate these relationships before you propose any reciprocity of promotion, but ultimately you can get to that. Being respected and liked by an influencer, even if not directly related to your niche is big. And influencers can introduce you to other influencers as well. This can ultimate get you speaking engagements, interviews, and/or promotion of your book, and so forth, depending upon the type of fame you are seeking. 6. Work on Your Fame Everyday This means many things. It can be to join new groups. It can mean to contact local media with a press release. It can mean creating amazing content or videos. It can mean reaching out to new communities on social media. But you must consistently commit to doing something every day to promote your fame. If you do this for an entire year, you will be pretty amazed at how famous you have become with your ideal audience. 7. Cultivate your Guru Status At first, you will give away a lot of stuff, maybe you will create free “how-to” e-guides. Maybe you will create slide shows and videos that provide expert advice. As the demand for your stuff grows, create new “stuff” and begin to charge for it. Why? Because famous people are expected to charge for their “stuff,” and because you have the right to earn money for your hard work. Neil Patel, the guru of content marketing, has the perfect combination. He is the co-founder of Crazy Egg, KISSmetrics, and Hello Bar. These are for-profit companies with famous clients like Amazon, GM, NBC, etc. He also has a blog, called Quick Sprout. Here he provides free educational articles for content marketers and business owners. But always on that blog, he is promoting his fee-based services, one of which is to make a business owner a “guru” and famous in his/her own niche. Becoming famous in a year is simple, but not necessarily easy. It takes concerted effort and a commitment that must be held every single day of that year. It means spending two hours working on that book; or it means an hour contacting local press to promote a charitable event; or it means writing the best content ever; or it mean networking and “rubbing elbows” with influencers. It can be tiring and it can mean that your workday just got longer. You have to ask yourself, before you take on this “fame” goal: why you want to become famous and what it will mean for you? If you can answer these questions positively, then you are ready for the journey. Make the Change You've Always Wanted Now! Read full profile Share Pin it Tweet Share Email Highly confident people believe in their ability to achieve. If you don’t believe in yourself, why should anyone else put their faith in you? To walk with swagger and improve your self-confidence, watch out for these fifteen things highly confident people don’t do. And if you want to know the difference between an arrogant person and a confident person, watch this video first: 1. They don’t make excuses. Highly confident people take ownership of their thoughts and actions. They don’t blame the traffic for being tardy at work; they were late. They don’t excuse their short-comings with excuses like “I don’t have the time” or “I’m just not good enough”; they make the time and they keep on improving until they are good enough. 2. They don’t avoid doing the scary thing. Highly confident people don’t let fear dominate their lives. They know that the things they are afraid of doing are often the very same things that they need to do in order to evolve into the person they are meant to be. 3. They don’t live in a bubble of comfort. Highly confident people avoid the comfort zone, because they know this is a place where dreams die. They actively pursue a feeling of discomfort, because they know stretching themselves is mandatory for their success. 4. They don’t put things off until next week. Highly confident people know that a good plan executed today is better than a great plan executed someday. They don’t wait for the “right time” or the “right circumstances”, because they know these reactions are based on a fear of change. They take action here, now, today – because that’s where progress happens. ⌄ Scroll down to continue reading article ⌄ Always Putting Things off Until Tomorrow? They don’t obsess over the opinions of others. Highly confident people don’t get caught up in negative feedback. While they do care about the well-being of others and aim to make a positive impact in the world, they don’t get caught up in negative opinions that they can’t do anything about. They know that their true friends will accept them as they are, and they don’t concern themselves with the rest. 6. They don’t judge people. Highly confident people have no tolerance for unnecessary, self-inflicted drama. They don’t feel the need to insult friends behind their backs, participate in gossip about fellow co-workers or lash out at folks with different opinions. They are so comfortable in who they are that they feel no need to look down on other people. 7. They don’t let lack of resources stop them. Highly confident people can make use of whatever resources they have, no matter how big or small. They know that all things are possible with creativity and a refusal to quit. They don’t agonize over setbacks, but rather focus on finding a solution. 8. They don’t make comparisons. Highly confident people know that they are not competing with any other person. They compete with no other individual except the person they were yesterday. They know that every person is living a story so unique that drawing comparisons would be an absurd and simplistic exercise in futility.

The reader will be surprised to see the conclusion. That it is differing from actual question and answer. But first let’s look for the general answer.  To be popular or appraised on Quora is not an easy task. It is hard-work, whole hearten work and finally a game, in a sense. And so is its unpredictability. In this platform, the failures may be quite sure and predictable but successes are rarely predictable. Still below are the prescribed tips, which I gathered through experience only: Select popular topics: Topics on nuclear and biochemistry may require more expertise but there are less readers to take interest and to understand and appreciate. A popular topic like tricks for banking , ticket booking, shopping, reservations require less expertise and there are millions interested who can appreciate. Further, it is better to stick to public topics, i.e. topics where masses are impacted directly and masses always find interest in them which may not be directly profitable to them. For example topics related to Brexit, American election, Demonetization in India. Remember that topics should be easily understandable and not highly technical like Mars Mission. There are only few takers on technical subjects like biotechnology, nuclear, microeconomics etc.Select popular questions: Answering directly to the 'requests' or top questions for you brings less views than answering on topics having more followers.Timing your answers: Answering too early or too late on current affair topics is worst. For example now is certainly not time to write on Brexit but may be little good time to write on Trump, the president-elect. If you are write very late...even the followers of questions do not take interest to read the answers as the are already saturated with lot of answers; the wave has lost the amplitude. Again writing too early is also not suggested. At very beginning their are very less followers to questions and less observers to the answers. Further, other writers, learning from the initial answers, gain knowledge, data, experience, manipulate and add their own and write further better answers.Complexity of hundreds of answers: If a question has many answers, like this one, then nobody is going to read all the answers. So your answers, when just written should be on upper side, best if on top. If the fresh answer slides below in the crowd of answer there is hardly any reader other than the writer's own followers. It can be avoided by points mentioned in line.Improving the presentation of answers: Answers with pictures or images are more attractive. Very short answers are mostly collapsed. Mostly answer should be explained at length. Very short, simple and straight answers are suitable for Quora-Messages and other social media platforms, not on Quora-Answers.Finally it is the quality of answers: If answers are really very good, all tricks, timings and follower base become secondary and answer views rises. If answer is selected to be on Quora digest, there is an exponential growth...however for one week only. Sometime even text only answers carry more views than picture inserted answers to the same question. Writes too have to be patient. As happens with me and almost all of us, few answers written loosely catches more views and few answers written carefully, with lot of research and expertise, with labor of about and hour, catches less views. Here there is less to do with writer's labor knowledge or expertise. But there is more to do with the popularity of question itself.An ironical example:  Indians love the legacy of former president Dr. Abdul Kalam. We used to like his story and vision on facebook/Quora written by even a random writer. Now imagine that Dr. Kalam is himself Quora user. Of course, his followers base will run to hundreds of thousands if not millions. Now further imagine that he himself writing his expert articles on cryogenic engine technology, propulsion engineering etc. How many of us will be able to understand and appreciate his sound technical answers. Except the technical field readers, the common users will slowly loose interest in his articles. The conclusion is something different. Yes, more views and upvotes makes writer feel better psychologically as well judge the quality of answer. But the writer should feel happy of his own work. This does not come to writers initially with high enthusiasm. This comes after a little maturity and understanding that more popularity is not necessarily an achievement. The natural enjoyment of writing or answering give far more happiness and peace of mind than the instability of mind due to hunger of views. Upvote to appreciate. Follow to get more on related topics.

I found it interesting and continued to complete the entire Curriculum for Living, Communication Course, Introduction Leader's Program and also participated in over 12 specialized programs offered by Landmark Education. So to summarize: 1. Find your passion.2. Figure out how you could use your passion to solve other people's problems3. I wanted to be popular in middle school and early high school. Wasn’t the best experience haha… I tried wearing the coolest brands of over-priced clothes that weren’t even that stylish, and I tried to have the same hobbies/interests as the cool kids. I watched TV shows and listened to music that I really didn’t like. I can only speak for myself, but I wanted to popular because I wanted to feel liked and wanted. I wanted people to know who I was and I wanted the feeling of being someone important in school. I wasn’t too confident in who I was during those times (Still working on it now haha). Once I realized that chasing popularity wasn’t what I truly wanted, then I focused my attention on creating long lasting friendships with 4–5 people and worked on the hobbies and interests that I actually enjoyed. The more I became confident in myself, the less I wanted to be popular. It’s really about who you are as a person and how you see yourself, not how others see you. The movie “Eighth Grade” directed by Bo Burnham was a really great film that I recommend watching about this topic. I’m sorry if if this wasn’t the answer you were expecting, but I hope this gives you a different perspective :p

As far as I can tell, there are two main ways to become famous in the entertainment industry. One of them is luck; not much to be said about this one as there’s very little one can do to influence it, apart from being ready to seize opportunities when they come (in your case, for example, you wouldn’t want to be taking a vacation from voice warm-ups or guitar practice and then be asked to perform the next day). Which leads me to the second way: practice and hard work. You have to be good to have any chance of being noticed, and to achieve that you have to work harder than you probably think you can. There’s a quote by J. M. Barrie that’s really helped me put that into perspective: “You can have anything in life if you will sacrifice everything else for it”. Find out what your priorities are. Finally, remember that fame does not usually happen overnight; most people who make it have worked very hard for many years. It’s not easy by any stretch of the imagination. This is something you have to know going in.

Go to the street corner with your guitar and a hat, stand there and sing like you’ve never sang before. Try different songs, different styles, different looks. Search for some traction. When you notice that particular songs get more attention and more coins, try to do more of that style of songs. When you notice that more people look based on your particular image, do more of that. Once you hone in on what works, record a video of you singing and post it on Youtube. Do the same thing on Youtube what you did on the street. Experiment with songs, lighting, images, until you gain traction and following. Keep doing it until you get very popular. Develop unique voice and persona. Reach out to the other rising stars on Youtube and form a band. Gain a huge fan base online and rule Youtube. Produce your own albums.

This question is asked over and over. Do you just want to be “famous” or do you want to achieve fame over something important or remarkable that you have accomplished? You can be famous for jumping off the top of the Empire State Building if you just want to achieve fame or you can be a serial killer. If you want to achieve fame for a legitimate purpose, work on a skill and concentrate on THAT instead of simply achieving fame. That seems to be a superfluous goal. I don’t mean to be critical of you, but I want to encourage you to focus on something constructive, of which you can actually be proud. I have to admit that this question makes me shake my head because I have worked with many “famous” people in entertainment and all of them have worked very hard to be good at what they do and fame is not always what it is cracked up to be.

Well, for a start, stop dwelling on the fact that you’re not popular. Ask yourself, why, you’re not popular. People will only like you, and want to be around you if you have something to offer.  May that be money, may that be love, may that be friendship and comfort, but you must have something people will like you by. “Wow, that’s such a great guy!” “He’s so kind!” “He’s rich and famous!” If you reek of negativity, uncleanliness, and hate, people naturally, will not like you. Do something to benefit society as a whole! Do something that makes you a better person, and then, people will flock over to you. Say Hi, Hello, or whatever, but always make sure to use their name. People are closer to you when you use their name.  Give genuine compliments! It works, and it destroys whatever negativity is present.  But again, do not dwell on the fact that you want to be popular. It shows, and people will move away from you if you do. Try it, and I hope this helps. ARMAAN AGRAWAL

1. Put yourself first Whatever life you want to succeed in, you need to learn to take care of yourself. If you can't put yourself first, you won't find balance in life. In this case, the famous actress Emma Thompson says to look at her physical and mental health. Then come the people closest to you, that is, family and close people. Keep up to date with the daily news of their lives. "Although it may be difficult to do this at Rose, try." Then start your own work. 2. Don't stop moving forward Edith Edge, a psychologist returning from the Auschwitz concentration camp in Germany during World War II, has always considered himself a mountaineer. "When a mountaineer starts climbing, he slips, goes down two or three steps. But he doesn't stop climbing. I slip like that, but I don't stop climbing, I never stop. " Edith's parents were executed at the Auschwitz concentration camp, she survived. He later moved to the United States to study psychology. "People will be able to kill me, torture me. But no one will be able to finish my soul and the consciousness of moving forward." 3. No need to think about what others are thinking Famous comedian and author Joe Brand say you don't need others to care about you. Because you can believe what you think about yourself without the approval of others. "I don't care what others think of me. I like my own look, but a lot of other people don't seem to like it." "I've learned to believe, it's not always important how I look." "It's not a big deal for my friends or those who love me. I think it's important to remember." 4. Change perspectives Many times at some bad moment we think we are buried, or we have drowned. But that can be thought of differently, as we can think of something new being sown. Actress Kelsey O'Keefe says, "I firmly believe that you have to decide how you feel about your life or your decision. We need to make it a habit to look positively. " "Drowning or sowing seeds --- both are happening under the ground or underwater. But in two cases it means two things, one of them expresses a very negative attitude. The other is a positive attitude, which impresses your thinking process. " "There are many moments in my life when I feel like I'm dead, but in those moments I start all over again." 5. Stay around positive people Mary Portas, a marketing guru, says that if there are always positive people around her, she should not question her abilities or be hesitant about her failures. "In my agency, we hire people who are around to spread the light, not those who drown others in humiliation." "We like people who are always positive in all situations, agree to do everything, and give their best to get it," he says. "Those who are full of energy themselves can inspire others. If you want to improve, stay away from those who are depressed or arrogant." . Shake your head "Use your intelligence in any situation," said Edith Edge, a psychologist returning from the Oswego concentration camp. “My mother used to say we don’t know where to go, we don’t know what will happen in our lives. But just as others do not know what is inside our heads, no one can snatch it. " "I came to America empty-handed, didn't know English. But look, I graduated with honors from a well-known university in this country. I tell everyone, the greatest strength of a man is his ability to shake his head." . Give yourself occasional leave US author Michelle Lori says that it is not possible for a person to be successful in the same way all the time. And if you can't succeed, there is nothing to get confused about. "We are taught all the time we have to be able to do everything. We have to be creative all the time. But we also need time to rest and think anew. " "A person needs time to fill his inner void, as well as leisure to evaluate his own work." It could be five minutes at the end of the day, think about what you did throughout the day, how you did it, how you could do it better. Excluding phone calls at this time, just give yourself some time without watching TV. . Failure is not the end of life If you fail at something, don't think your life is over. Rather think it’s a ‘comma’ in your life meaning a short break, not a ‘full stop’ or end. Film personality Lily Collins says, "I always tell myself, something 'negative' means 'no', but it's 'not now'." There will be no tomorrow that is not or is not likely to happen now or in the present, it does not make sense.

I will answer your question based on a high schooler’s experience. To me, being popular means: Being pretty, having the latest luxury brands, having many friends, being able to hang out after school etc. I tried hard to fit in with the popular crowd, faked that I liked the things that they usually do, and kept hanging out after school. After all these, I still wasn’t ‘popular’. I realized that I had absolutely no potential to be ‘popular’. So, I just continued with my past so-called geeky ways( such as reading books on the bus/ studying hard). Believe it or not, I became much more known when I was smarter( at least in Math). You can actually be popular when you least expect it. I also realized that it doesn’t matter whether you are popular or not. What matters is if you have the true friends who will stick by you when times are tough. I realized many things.

The simplest way that can make you famous is your TALENT ,YesHave you seen that video made by yashraj (“Rasode me kaun tha) Before that video , he had 10K followers on instagram and some less than 10K subs on youtube.After that video, he became so viral that he was into news , there were articles about him, and now currently as of now he is having more than 700K followers and close to a million on youtube.Rasode mein kaun tha? – the question that has taken the internet by storm. Six days ago, when 24-year-old composer Yashraj Mukhate uploaded a 57-second video of him remixing a frivolous line of dialogue from a stereotypical TV soap opera, he didn’t anticipate getting almost 10 million views and becoming an internet sensation within a week. Mukhate’s comical twist on the hilariously exaggerated lines from Kokilaben – a fictional character from the 2010 Star Plus series Saath Nibhana Saathiya – has been shared far and wide, even by the likes of singer Prateek Kuhad and actors such as Rajkummar Rao, Taapsee Pannu and Varun Dhawan.

Being popular is overrated. The world is filled to its brim with attention seeking people who desire nothing more than to be rich, famous & popular. They go to great lengths in this bizarre pursuit of being well known, well liked & well paid. Popularity is not something you can simply create. It comes from something inside of you, whether it's a true talent or artistic expression. In these times it can also come from doing dangerous & downright stupid things in order to garner attention & “likes.” My best advice for anyone wanting to be popular is to try & be 100% genuine YOU & if people like you, great! If people don't, so what? Unless you have serious personality flaws or habits that disturb or annoy people, you'll be as popular as you can by just being the best & most authentic you.

More people will like you and follow you -Care about your fans and followers and thank them after reaching a certain amount. Don’t look at them as a number. See them as individuals Good luck 🍀👍🏻

I would think you might want to distinguish what you want to be famous for or at. There are a couple of types of fame, the end result is you are famous, but is it the kind of fame you desired? Notoriety goes a long way in the game of fame, Madonna would be a good example, so would Tracy Lords. Distinguish the kind of fame your seeking, then ask yourself if you’re ready for the moment? with that fame comes a responsibility, are you ready for that? Now you’re on a pedestal in the spotlight, with several looking up to you, will you be the one to let them down? If fame is what you seek, it isn’t hard to obtain, it just depends on how you go about it. Personally speaking, you may find that fame seeks you if you’re doing something right, those seeking fame, a lot of times wind up in a bad way. Good Luck! Robert

You become popular by being yourself. Popularity and cliques are all about highschool. Once you leave highschool no one cares if you were a cheerleader or the quarterback. No one cares when you get to college or in the real world. You will meet new people and being “popular”will be a thing of the past. Popularity can bring it's own downfalls: jealousy from others lack of compassion for others, having a hard time adjusting to new situations where highschool popularity doesn't matter anymore. No one cares when you move beyond highschool. College or the real world will bring a whole new set of people and opportunities. Do you think people actually ask you if you were popular in highschool? Doesn't usually happen. In the meantime develop your own skills and hobbies: music, sports, anything that makes you, you. No one can be you. A special skill sets you apart from others and other people want to be a part of that. That is why popularity exists; because people want to hang around the people they admire..for whatever reason. Become a musician, an artist, get on a team. Be good at whatever you choose and the rest will follow.

Well, you can’t “make” yourself popular, but what you can do is become very interested in other people. If you feel “unpopular”, I’d bet that you’re concentrating on that feeling and not showing much interest in other people. What people LIKE is people who like and are really interested in THEM. A person who is really interested in ME is almost irresistible to me. How can you not like someone who already likes you? The way you can do this is to wonder what other people’s lives are like - what do they read, what do they do with their time, what are their families like, their children if any. How about pets - that’s always a good way to meet strangers. In other words, though this may sound strange - the way to BE popular is to make someone else popular to yourself; thinking about them, wondering about them, talking to them, finding out about them, helping them with something, appreciating them, complimenting them. Don’t worry - you’ll get it all back in terms of friendship and that’s what you’re after, isn’t it?
